participants: georgia chestnuts rust-ing on an open fire

messages.sender: georgia chestnuts rust-ing on an open fire
messages.message: Hi folks :wave: does anyone know why we refer to MSFT's OCR as Marx on Instabase.com (http://Instabase.com)? Is this what is was previously called before Computer Vision?
That’s always been our code name for microsoft ocr.

messages.sender: georgia chestnuts rust-ing on an open fire
messages.message: Thank you @Heymian do you know if there is any reason we don’t want to label them OCR engines what they are called actually? I think we should call the MSFT one Computer Vision and others what they are called.

historically we avoided all mention of the actual OCR engine because we presented to the customer the “Instabase OCR” engine as the state of the art one. And we didn’t want to leak what libraries we were actually using.
This is why we use the code name in the UI and all the logs.
Customers like SC have challenged us with claims like “if your just using Abbyy, then why do we need you, we can just use Abbyy ourselves”.
But if we’re openly advertising Microsoft, and it’s a bonus add to do so, I see no reason to codeify it. But probably not my call. :slightly_smiling_face:

messages.sender: georgia chestnuts rust-ing on an open fire
messages.message: This is good context, thank you!!

haha wanted to edit the SC one. We actually lost a couple of months to a “competition”/“argument” where we had to prove that our product with Abbyy was better than them trying to use Abbyy themselves.
related to this convo, https://instabase.atlassian.net/browse/IBG-60 please weigh in on that Jira issue if we want to/do not want to reveal the OCR magic behind the Instabase curtain
I think this convo is a bit different from that JIRA (based on a quick skim)?
This is a broader decision (ultimately Anant) on how we want to sell/market Instabase’s technology.
I believe “Default” and “HQ Scanned Docs” are the only OCR models which need to be kept under codenames, everything else can be reverted to the actual company’s OCR model

“Default” and “HQ Scanned Docs” are special because we don’t want to reveal that we may be using Abbyy as our Default or Abbyy to run HQ Scanned Docs. For example, we may decide to change the OCR model for HQ Scanned Docs to Microsoft because we now believe that is better.

So those two names are special, and mainly it’s about not talking about ABBYY to our customers
and agree with Heymian’s comments above
